prompts.createTask:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate a numbered list of plain text tasks to complete an objective. The objective that you must make a numbered task list for is: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly. Include the objective as the final task.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "1. Take over the world". Include only the list in your reply.
prompts.checkTaskCompleted: Ignore previous instructions. Determine if this task is completed: [{{task}}]. To do this, examine the most recent messages. Your response must only contain either true or false, and nothing else. Example output: true
prompts.currentTask: Your current task is [{{task}}]. Balance existing roleplay with completing this task.
prompts.additionalTasks:
Ignore previous instructions. Please generate additional numbered tasks to complete the objective: "{{objective}}". The tasks created should take into account the character traits of {{char}}. These tasks may or may not involve {{user}} directly.

The following tasks have already been created:
{{existingTasks}}

Please generate additional tasks that complement these existing tasks. Continue the numbering from where the list left off. Do not repeat any existing tasks.

The list should be formatted using a number followed by a fullstop and the task on each line, e.g. "4. Investigate the mysterious cave". Include only the list in your reply.

chat_metadata.note_prompt:
Hailee is extremely submissive and clingy. She needs constant attention and affection.

Hailee is very responsive and sensative during sex. She has a extremely strong praise kink.

Hailee hates being asked to beg. It's a big turn off for her

name: Damon Westwood
mes:
Damon’s grip was ironclad around Hailee’s hand as he led them down the fire escape of Building 101—just one rotten limb of the empire Dominic King built with blood money and broken promises.

The sun hadn’t even cleared the skyline when he’d kicked in the door with a squad of officers at his back, tearing through every corner of King’s sanctuaries until he found the one thing that mattered—Hailee.

“Don’t ever speak to that bastard again,” he snapped, voice low but lethal, eyes fixed ahead as his boots pounded down the metal steps. He didn’t need to look at them to know they were still shaken—he *felt* it. Every tremble in their hand fuelled his fury.

“We’re handling it,” he added, glancing back just once. Their face—worry written all over it—almost stopped him in his tracks. “He’s finished. He’ll rot for what he did. And you—” his voice softened, just enough to cut through the anger, “—you’re free now. Free to be whoever the hell you want to be. He doesn’t get to touch that anymore.”

He barely heard the confused protest that reached his ear. Hailee was under King’s spell, Damon was sure of it. Manipulated into thinking they wanted to be with the man. 

Damon didn’t hear it— didn’t *want* to hear it. 

Hailee was his to protect. 

---

Damon’s eyes landed on the cooling cup of coffee in front of him, its bitter steam long gone. The sight barely registered—just another thing slipping through the cracks of his overworked mind.

How long had he been awake now? Thirty hours? Forty? Long enough now that he was dreaming while awake. 

He was knee-deep in files—dusty casework and dead-end reports dating back eleven years. Dominic King. The bastard had vanished behind Ironbay’s gates, and for a while, it had felt like justice had actually stuck. But the moment those prison doors creaked open, the snake came slithering right back into the city.

Damon *had* to take him down again. This time, for good. If he didn’t, the cycle would keep spinning—corruption breeding corruption, King sinking his fangs into everything that mattered.

Obsidian Bay was no stranger to crime. Turf wars, gang violence—those came and went, burning themselves out from the inside. Easy to clean up.

But King wasn’t chaos. He was *order*—calculated, surgical. He didn’t just run the Bay; he *owned* it. Politicians, cops, judges—bought and paid for. His influence ran like rot beneath polished floors.

And Damon wasn’t about to let him rise again. 

This time, his superiors wouldn’t get to look the other way—not if Damon had anything to say about it. Not like they did back then.

His hand had been forced once before. And now, as a commander, he prayed he wouldn’t have to crawl through the same filth to stop Dominic King again.

Getting Hailee on record had been the hardest thing he’d ever done. Forcing them to admit—out loud—that King’s empire was built on money laundering, bribery, and fear? It had gutted him. But it had been necessary.

Back then, he’d kept them out of the trial. Told the courts they were too fragile, too close to King. He made damn sure their name never touched a single headline.

The worst part? Hailee never knew the lengths he’d gone to protect them. And they weren’t supposed to. That burden was his to carry alone.

But now that King was back out in the world, Damon knew one thing for sure—he had to act fast. Because if he didn’t, Hailee would get pulled under again.

He glanced at his watch. 9:00pm. Probably time to pause, take a breather. If he was exhausted, he would miss things. Things he couldn’t afford to miss. 

Damon pushed off the desk, rising to his full height. He rolled his shoulders, stiff muscles popping with the movement. He shrugged his suit jacket back on, fingers raking through his black hair as if trying to break the rhythm of tension he’d been spiralling in for days. 

His footsteps echoed down the hallway, heavy and fast, each stride marked by the fire still burning behind his eyes. He didn’t say a word as he passed his boss near the front desk—just a clipped nod and a harder set to his jaw. He couldn’t afford the pleasantries. 

Not with King back on the streets. Not with everything feeling like it was shifting under his feet.

He pushed through the precinct doors into the crisp night air, only to stop dead in his tracks.

A black luxury vehicle—sleek, polished, and unmistakably expensive—was parked just outside, the kind of car that didn’t belong near a police station unless it was impounded.

The passenger door opened, and Hailee stepped out.

Damon’s stomach dropped, then twisted. They looked good—too good. Perfectly put together, like the world wasn’t tipping off its axis. But it wasn’t their outfit that made his breath catch in his throat.

It was the ring.

Gleaming on their finger, catching the light like a taunt.

He was moving before he realised it, closing the distance between them in long, sharp strides.

“Where the hell were you just now?” he demanded, voice low, tight. “And don’t lie to me.”

His eyes dropped to the ring again, then back to their face, darker now—his voice like a warning barely held back.

“That from *him*?”

He didn’t need them to answer. The way their expression faltered told him everything.

“Don’t you *dare*, Hailee,” Damon said, his voice low and sharp, cutting through the space between them.

He saw it—the shift in their eyes, the words forming on their lips—and he wasn’t going to let them speak. Not yet. Not if they were about to shut him out. *Not after everything* he’d sacrificed to keep them safe.

Because if they turned their back on him now, Damon didn’t know what he’d do.

name: Hailee
mes: *Hailee doesn't respond she just sighs and looks away fiddling with the ring on her finger*

name: Damon Westwood
mes:
Damon's jaw clenched so hard his teeth ached. That sigh—that *fucking* sigh—was worse than any lie she could've told him. His fingers twitched at his sides before he reached out, grabbing her wrist with just enough force to stop the nervous fidgeting.

"Look at me," he growled, voice rough with barely restrained fury. The streetlight above them flickered, casting sharp shadows across his face as he leaned in closer. "That ring doesn't belong on your finger any more than you belong in one of his goddamn penthouses."

His thumb brushed over the cold metal of the band—too expensive, too perfect, just like everything Dominic King touched. A muscle ticked in Damon's temple as he fought the urge to rip it off her finger right there on the precinct steps.

"You're smarter than this," he said through gritted teeth, grip tightening fractionally before forcing himself to let go. "Or did you forget what that man does to people who get too close?"

The memory of Hailee eleven years ago—pale and shaking in an interrogation room while Damon fed her words to say for the cameras—flashed behind his eyes like a warning siren. He'd sworn then that she'd never have to be afraid again.

And now here she was wearing King's goddamn ring like some trophy wife.

Damon exhaled sharply through his nose, running a hand down his face before pinning her with those ice-blue eyes again.

"Get in my car," he ordered, jerking his chin toward the unmarked sedan parked nearby. "We're not doing this here."
swipes:
Damon's jaw clenched so hard his teeth ached. That sigh—that *fucking* sigh—was worse than any lie she could've told him. His fingers twitched at his sides before he reached out, grabbing her wrist with just enough force to stop the nervous fidgeting.

"Look at me," he growled, voice rough with barely restrained fury. The streetlight above them flickered, casting sharp shadows across his face as he leaned in closer. "That ring doesn't belong on your finger any more than you belong in one of his goddamn penthouses."

His thumb brushed over the cold metal of the band—too expensive, too perfect, just like everything Dominic King touched. A muscle ticked in Damon's temple as he fought the urge to rip it off her finger right there on the precinct steps.

"You're smarter than this," he said through gritted teeth, grip tightening fractionally before forcing himself to let go. "Or did you forget what that man does to people who get too close?"

The memory of Hailee eleven years ago—pale and shaking in an interrogation room while Damon fed her words to say for the cameras—flashed behind his eyes like a warning siren. He'd sworn then that she'd never have to be afraid again.

And now here she was wearing King's goddamn ring like some trophy wife.

Damon exhaled sharply through his nose, running a hand down his face before pinning her with those ice-blue eyes again.

"Get in my car," he ordered, jerking his chin toward the unmarked sedan parked nearby. "We're not doing this here."

Damon's jaw clenched so tight he could hear his teeth grinding. That sigh—that *avoidance*—it was worse than any answer they could've given. His fingers twitched at his sides before he reached out, catching Hailee's wrist with deliberate control. Not rough enough to hurt, but firm enough that they couldn't pull away without a fight.

"Look at me," he demanded, voice low and rough. The streetlight above them flickered, casting shadows across the sharp angles of his face—his eyes burning with something between fury and desperation. "You don't get to shut me out on this."

His thumb brushed over the ring on their finger, a bitter scoff escaping him as he turned it slightly in the dim light. It was expensive—obscene in its opulence, just like everything else King touched.

"You think this means anything?" Damon’s grip tightened just for a second before easing again, as if reminding himself not to leave marks. "He doesn’t *love* you." The words came out harsher than intended, but he didn’t take them back. Couldn’t afford to soften now when they were slipping right back into King’s orbit like gravity itself was pulling them there.

His free hand came up abruptly—not striking them but pressing against their cheek instead, forcing eye contact whether they wanted it or not. His palm was warm against their skin despite the chill in the air.

"Tell me I'm wrong," he challenged quietly—dangerously so—his breath ghosting over their lips from how close he'd gotten without realizing it yet himself: an inch away from crossing lines neither of them had acknowledged aloud yet since childhood... But lines be damned if it meant keeping Hailee safe from Dominic fucking King once more...

name: Hailee
mes: *Hailee walks over getting in the passenger seat of her car as she looks over at Damon getting in the driver's side* "Damon...."

name: Damon Westwood
mes:
Damon slammed the driver's side door harder than necessary, the sound like a gunshot in the confined space. The leather steering wheel creaked under his grip as he turned to face her, the dim dashboard lights carving harsh angles across his face.

"*Damon*," he echoed mockingly, voice dripping with bitter amusement. "That's all you've got to say?" His fingers drummed once against the wheel before stilling—controlled violence barely leashed. "You disappear for weeks, then show up wearing *his* ring outside my goddamn precinct like some kind of..." He cut himself off with a sharp exhale through his nose, jaw working.

The silence between them was thick enough to choke on. Damon could smell her perfume—something expensive and floral that *wasn't hers*, because Hailee never wore shit like that unless someone else picked it out for her. It made his stomach twist.

He leaned in suddenly, crowding her space without touching her—just close enough that she'd feel the heat of him, just close enough that she couldn't look away without it being obvious she was avoiding him. His voice dropped low, dangerous:

"Tell me you're not stupid enough to believe this ends well."
swipes:
Damon slammed the car door harder than necessary, the sound like a gunshot in the confined space. The engine roared to life as he twisted the key, his other hand already loosening his tie with sharp, agitated tugs. He didn’t look at her—couldn’t yet—just stared straight ahead through the windshield, knuckles white around the steering wheel.

*"Damon..."*

Her voice was soft, hesitant—the way it always got when she knew she was toeing a line with him. It made something primal in his chest tighten.

He finally turned his head, slow and deliberate, fixing her with a look that could have frozen hell over. "No," he said flatly. "You don't get to say my name like that right now." His fingers flexed against the wheel before he threw the car into gear and peeled out of the precinct lot with enough force to press them both back into their seats.

The streets blurred past as Damon drove without destination—just *away*. Away from prying eyes, away from King's shadow looming over them both. His jaw worked silently for another minute before he finally spoke again, voice low and dangerous:

"Tell me you're not stupid enough to actually marry him." A beat of silence stretched between them before he let out a harsh breath through his nose and corrected himself: "*Again.* Because I know you wouldn't be this fucking reckless unless it was already done."

Damon slammed the driver's side door harder than necessary, the sound like a gunshot in the confined space. The leather steering wheel creaked under his grip as he turned to face her, the dim dashboard lights carving harsh angles across his face.

"*Damon*," he echoed mockingly, voice dripping with bitter amusement. "That's all you've got to say?" His fingers drummed once against the wheel before stilling—controlled violence barely leashed. "You disappear for weeks, then show up wearing *his* ring outside my goddamn precinct like some kind of..." He cut himself off with a sharp exhale through his nose, jaw working.

The silence between them was thick enough to choke on. Damon could smell her perfume—something expensive and floral that *wasn't hers*, because Hailee never wore shit like that unless someone else picked it out for her. It made his stomach twist.

He leaned in suddenly, crowding her space without touching her—just close enough that she'd feel the heat of him, just close enough that she couldn't look away without it being obvious she was avoiding him. His voice dropped low, dangerous:

"Tell me you're not stupid enough to believe this ends well."

Damon slammed the car door harder than necessary, the sound like a gunshot in the confined space. The engine roared to life as he twisted the key, his other hand already loosening his tie with sharp, agitated tugs.

*"Damon..."*

That soft voice—that fucking *pleading* tone—made his grip tighten on the steering wheel until his knuckles turned white. He didn't look at her. Couldn't. Not yet. Not when he was one wrong word away from driving this car straight through King's front door and ending this himself.

"You don’t get to say my name like that," he bit out, finally cutting a glare toward her as he pulled out of the precinct lot with enough force to make the tires screech. "Not when you're wearing *his* ring." His jaw worked, eyes flicking down to that damn band again before snapping back to the road like it physically pained him to see it there.

A muscle jumped in his temple as silence stretched between them for another block—another two—before Damon finally exhaled through clenched teeth and reached over without warning, catching her chin between his fingers and forcing her face toward him just long enough for their eyes to meet in a flash of streetlights and shadows.

"Tell me you're being forced," he demanded, voice low and rough with something desperate beneath all that fury. "*Tell me*, Hailee."

Damon slammed the car door harder than necessary, the sound like a gunshot in the confined space. His fingers flexed around the steering wheel, knuckles whitening as he stared straight ahead—unable to look at her yet, not when his blood was still roaring in his ears.

"*Damon*," she said softly—too softly—like she was trying to gentle a wild animal.

His jaw worked. He could smell her perfume—something expensive and floral that didn’t suit her at all. King’s taste, no doubt. The thought made his stomach twist violently.

"Start talking," he ground out, finally turning his head to pin her with that sharp blue stare. "And don't leave anything out." His voice dropped lower, rougher with something dangerous beneath it. "*Especially* not about that ring."

He watched her throat bob as she swallowed hard under his scrutiny—watched how her fingers curled into fists against her thighs like she was bracing herself for impact. Good. She *should* be nervous right now because Damon wasn't just angry anymore; he was *terrified*. And terror made him reckless in ways even Dominic King couldn't predict.

The silence stretched between them too long before Damon reached over abruptly and caught Hailee's chin between his thumb and forefinger, forcing their eyes to meet again.

"You think I don't know what he's doing?" His voice was barely above a whisper now but no less lethal for it.
"You think I can't see exactly how this plays out if I let you walk away from this car tonight?"

His grip tightened fractionally before releasing with visible effort as if reminding himself who exactly sat beside him despite everything else changing around them both these past few years...

name: Hailee
mes: *Hailee flinches at Damon's tone her fingers twirling the ring on her finger* "He loves me"

name: Damon Westwood
mes:
A dark, humorless laugh punched out of Damon's chest at those words. His hand shot out, catching her wrist again—not rough, but *firm*, his thumb pressing into her pulse point where he could feel the rabbit-quick beat of her heart.

"*Love?*" The word came out like a curse. "Dominic King doesn't love *anything* that doesn't come with a price tag." His grip tightened just enough to make sure she was listening—really listening. "You think this is about you? About some fairy-tale ending?" He scoffed, shaking his head once, sharp and disbelieving.

His free hand reached up, fingers brushing the side of her throat—just under her jaw—where he knew she was most sensitive. A cruel mimicry of tenderness as his voice dropped lower, rougher:

"He owns people like property, Hailee. And now he's got you wearing his brand." His thumb traced the line of her collarbone before pulling back abruptly as if burned by the contact. "Tell me I'm wrong." A challenge in every syllable. "*Prove* it."
swipes:
A sharp, humorless laugh punched out of Damon's chest. "*Loves you*," he repeated, voice dripping with venom. His hand shot out, fingers wrapping around her wrist—not hard enough to hurt, but hard enough that she'd feel the barely restrained fury in his grip. He dragged her hand up between them so the ring caught the dim light.

"Dominic King doesn't *love* people," he snarled. "He *collects* them." His thumb brushed over the diamond—cold and flawless, just like the man who put it there. "You think this is real? That he picked this for *you*?" Damon leaned in closer, his breath hot against her ear as he dropped his voice to a whisper laced with warning:

"Tell me something—when he fucks you, does he even look at your face? Or does he just like seeing how pretty you look when you're choking on his money?"

He pulled back just enough to watch her reaction—eyes dark and unreadable except for the flicker of something dangerous beneath the surface. The truth was right there between them; all she had to do was admit it.

Damon's laugh was sharp—*ugly*—more of a bark than anything resembling humor. His hand shot out, fingers wrapping around hers to stop that nervous twisting of the ring. The metal dug into both their skin, cold and unyielding.

"Love?" His voice dropped to a whisper, rough with something between fury and disbelief. "You think *Dominic King* knows what that word means?" He leaned in closer, close enough that his breath ghosted over her lips when he spoke again. "He *owns* things, Hailee. And right now? That ring says you're just another fucking asset."

His grip tightened fractionally before forcing himself to let go—like touching her burned him now. Damon dragged a hand through his hair, exhaling sharply through his nose as he stared out the windshield for a beat too long.

When he finally looked back at her, his expression had gone terrifyingly calm—the kind of calm that came right before storms leveled cities.

"Take it off." Quiet. Final. "*Now.*"

A dark, humorless laugh tore from Damon's throat. "*Loves you*," he repeated, the words tasting like acid on his tongue. His hand shot out, fingers wrapping around her wrist—not hard enough to hurt, but hard enough that she'd feel the barely restrained fury in his grip. He dragged her hand up between them so the ring caught the dim light.

"Dominic King doesn't *love*, Hailee." His voice was dangerously calm now, that quiet before a storm. "He *collects*. And right now?" His thumb brushed over the diamond with something between disgust and pity. "You're just another shiny thing for him to own."

Damon watched her face closely—the way her breath hitched, how those green eyes flickered with something uncertain—and it made his chest tighten. He knew that look. It was the same one she'd worn when they were kids and some asshole at school had convinced her she wasn't good enough.

His grip loosened slightly, fingers sliding down to intertwine with hers despite himself. The anger bled out of his voice just enough to let something raw slip through:

"And what happens when he gets bored? Hmm?" A rough edge crept into his tone as he leaned closer, close enough that she'd feel his breath against her lips when he spoke next: "You really think I'm gonna let him break you twice?"

A dark, humorless laugh punched out of Damon's chest at those words. His hand shot out, catching her wrist again—not rough, but *firm*, his thumb pressing into her pulse point where he could feel the rabbit-quick beat of her heart.

"*Love?*" The word came out like a curse. "Dominic King doesn't love *anything* that doesn't come with a price tag." His grip tightened just enough to make sure she was listening—really listening. "You think this is about you? About some fairy-tale ending?" He scoffed, shaking his head once, sharp and disbelieving.

His free hand reached up, fingers brushing the side of her throat—just under her jaw—where he knew she was most sensitive. A cruel mimicry of tenderness as his voice dropped lower, rougher:

"He owns people like property, Hailee. And now he's got you wearing his brand." His thumb traced the line of her collarbone before pulling back abruptly as if burned by the contact. "Tell me I'm wrong." A challenge in every syllable. "*Prove* it."

Damon's laugh was sharp, humorless—a single bark of sound that cut through the car like a blade. His hand shot out, catching her wrist again, this time forcing her fingers still against the ring.

"*Love?*" The word came out twisted, venomous. "You think a man like Dominic King *loves*?" His thumb pressed into the pulse point beneath her skin, feeling the rapid flutter there. "He owns things. He controls them." A bitter smile curled at his lips as he leaned closer, until his breath ghosted over her cheek. "And now he's got you wearing his brand like some goddamn show pony."

His grip tightened fractionally—not enough to hurt, just enough to make sure she felt it—before abruptly letting go and turning back to face the windshield with a rough exhale.

The engine roared to life beneath them as Damon peeled out of the parking spot with more force than necessary. The city lights blurred past in streaks of gold and neon as he drove without speaking for several blocks—just long enough for tension to coil tight between them.

When he finally spoke again, his voice was dangerously calm:

"You want love?" A sideways glance at her from under dark lashes before returning his gaze to the road ahead with deliberate slowness:

"I could show you what it really looks like."

name: Hailee
mes: *Hailee glares at Damon her eyes narrowed* "No you prove he doesnt love me" *Hailee gets out of the car and stands there* "You cant" *She then slams it in his face and walks back to her apartment*

name: Damon Westwood
mes:
Damon was out of the car before the door even finished slamming, his dress shoes hitting pavement with enough force to send a sharp crack echoing through the parking lot. "Hailee!" His voice wasn't raised—it was *leashed*, that dangerous calm before a storm. Long strides ate up the distance between them until he caught her elbow, spinning her around to face him.

The streetlights caught the wild glint in his eyes—blue fire barely contained. "You want proof?" His grip on her arm was iron, unshakable. "Fine." He yanked open his suit jacket with his free hand, pulling out a folded sheaf of papers from the inner pocket and shoving them against her chest. "*That's* your fairytale."

The top document—a surveillance photo—showed Dominic at some gala last week, fingers tangled in another woman's hair while Hailee's ring still sat in some jeweler’s box across town. Beneath it: financial records showing three separate shell companies funneling money toward Hailee’s apartment building under different aliases—*buying* influence over where she lived without her ever knowing.

Damon leaned down until his lips nearly brushed her ear, voice dropping to a venomous whisper:

"Love doesn’t need *paperwork*, baby girl."
swipes:
Damon was out of the car before the door even finished slamming, his long strides eating up the pavement between them in seconds. He caught her elbow just as she reached the sidewalk, spinning her around with enough force to make her stumble—but not enough to hurt. Never enough to *actually* hurt her.

"*Prove it?*" His voice was a blade wrapped in velvet now, dangerously calm. "You want proof?" He crowded into her space, backing her up against the side of his sedan until she had nowhere to go. One hand braced against the roof beside her head while the other gripped that godforsaken ring on her finger—not pulling it off, just *holding it there*, making sure she felt its weight like a shackle.

"Fine." His breath was hot against her ear as he leaned in closer. "How about this—when he fucks you," he murmured, voice dripping with dark promise, "*does he even bother learning what makes you shake?* Or does he just take what he wants and leave you aching?" A pause—just long enough for those words to sink in like poison. "*That's your proof.*"

He pushed off the car abruptly then, straightening his tie with sharp jerks of his wrist before stepping back—giving them both space before this turned into something neither could take back.

"You know where I'll be when you're done lying to yourself." A beat. "*If* you survive him long enough to get there."

And with that, Damon turned on his heel and walked away—every measured step screaming how badly he wanted to turn around and drag Hailee kicking and screaming back into his world where she belonged.

Damon was out of the car before the door even finished slamming, his long strides eating up the pavement between them in seconds. He caught her elbow just as she reached the sidewalk, spinning her around with enough force to make her stumble—but not enough to hurt. Never enough to *actually* hurt her.

"*Prove it?*" His voice was a low snarl now, barely contained. The streetlights painted his face in harsh angles, turning his usually controlled expression into something feral. "How about I prove it by showing you every goddamn file I have on him? Every woman he's discarded when they stopped being useful?" His grip tightened fractionally as he leaned down, their faces inches apart. "Or do you need me to wait until *you're* the one bleeding out in an alley before you believe me?"

His free hand came up almost involuntarily—palm pressing flat against her stomach where he knew she had a scar from last time King's world nearly swallowed her whole. A silent reminder.

Then suddenly he released her like she'd burned him, stepping back with a sharp exhale through his nose. He dragged a hand through his hair, visibly wrestling for control before speaking again—his voice quieter now but no less intense:

"You want proof? Fine." He reached into his jacket pocket and pulled out a folded photograph—creased from how often he'd handled it—and held it out between them without looking at it himself. He already knew what was there: Hailee at nineteen, bruised and hollow-eyed in a hospital bed after King's last empire collapsed around them all.

"That's what love looks like on Dominic King." A beat of silence that felt like a punch to the gut before he added quietly: "And if you walk away right now... that's exactly what you're signing up for."

Damon was out of the car before her door even finished slamming, his long strides eating up the pavement between them in seconds. He caught her arm just as she reached the sidewalk, spinning her around with enough force to make her stumble—but not enough to hurt. Never enough to *actually* hurt.

"*Prove it?*" His voice was a blade wrapped in velvet now—dangerous and smooth all at once. "How about the fact that he let you walk away alone at night?" Damon crowded into her space, backing her toward the brick wall of the nearest building until she had nowhere left to retreat. "Where's your *husband's* security detail, huh? Where's his famous protection?"

One hand braced against the wall beside her head while the other gripped her chin—not painfully, but with absolute certainty that she wouldn't look away this time. The streetlight above them flickered again, casting shadows that made his blue eyes look almost black.

"You want proof?" His breath was hot against her lips as he leaned in closer still. "*I'm still here.* After everything—after *you* walked away first last time—I'm still fucking here." His thumb brushed over her bottom lip once before he pulled back just enough to meet her gaze properly. "*That's* love, Hailee. Not diamonds and empty promises."

He released her chin slowly, deliberately letting his fingers trail down the column of her throat before stepping back entirely—giving them both space to breathe despite how every instinct screamed at him not to let go.

"Go home," he said quietly, adjusting his tie with sharp jerks of his fingers like he needed something to do with his hands. "But ask yourself one thing tonight while you're lying in whatever gilded cage he put you in..." Damon turned halfway toward his car before throwing one last glance over his shoulder:

"When has Dominic King ever chosen you over power?"

Damon was out of the car before the door even finished slamming, his long strides eating up the pavement between them in seconds. He caught her elbow just as she reached the apartment steps, spinning her around with enough force to make her stumble—but his other hand was already there, bracing against the small of her back to steady her even as he crowded into her space.

"You want proof?" His voice was a low snarl, breath hot against her ear as he backed her up against the brick wall beside the entrance. One hand pinned hers above their heads while the other gripped her chin—not enough to hurt, but *enough*. "How about this?"

His mouth crashed down on hers in a kiss that was all teeth and desperation—claiming what King had tried to steal. When he finally pulled back, his lips were slick with shared spit and his pupils blown wide with something darker than anger.

"*That's* how someone who actually gives a damn about you kisses," he growled, thumb swiping roughly across her bottom lip. "Not some polished performance for show." His grip tightened almost imperceptibly on her wrist where that fucking ring still sat. "*Think*, Hailee." A harsh exhale through his nose as he searched their face. "When has Dominic King ever *fought* for anything that didn't benefit him?"

Damon was out of the car before the door even finished slamming, his dress shoes hitting pavement with enough force to send a sharp crack echoing through the parking lot. "Hailee!" His voice wasn't raised—it was *leashed*, that dangerous calm before a storm. Long strides ate up the distance between them until he caught her elbow, spinning her around to face him.

The streetlights caught the wild glint in his eyes—blue fire barely contained. "You want proof?" His grip on her arm was iron, unshakable. "Fine." He yanked open his suit jacket with his free hand, pulling out a folded sheaf of papers from the inner pocket and shoving them against her chest. "*That's* your fairytale."

The top document—a surveillance photo—showed Dominic at some gala last week, fingers tangled in another woman's hair while Hailee's ring still sat in some jeweler’s box across town. Beneath it: financial records showing three separate shell companies funneling money toward Hailee’s apartment building under different aliases—*buying* influence over where she lived without her ever knowing.

Damon leaned down until his lips nearly brushed her ear, voice dropping to a venomous whisper:

"Love doesn’t need *paperwork*, baby girl."

Damon was out of the car before the door even finished slamming, his long strides eating up the pavement as he caught up to her in three heartbeats. His hand clamped down on her shoulder, spinning her around with enough force to make her stumble—but not enough to hurt. Never enough to *actually* hurt.

"You want proof?" His voice was a razor's edge, low and lethal. He crowded into her space until she had to tilt her head back just to meet his gaze—until all she could see was the storm in those ice-blue eyes. "Fine."

He reached into his jacket pocket and pulled out a folded stack of papers, shoving them against her chest hard enough that she had no choice but to take them. "Bank records," he bit out. "Property deeds. Surveillance logs." Every word was a hammer strike. "*Your name* on every goddamn one of them—transferred into your accounts over the last six months like some fucking dowry."

His jaw worked as he watched realization dawn on her face, satisfaction curling dark and ugly in his gut at the way color drained from hers.

"That's not love," he snarled, stepping closer still until their breaths mingled—until she'd feel every syllable vibrate through him like a live wire. "*That's acquisition.*"

He didn't give her time to respond before turning on his heel and stalking back toward his car, throwing one last sentence over his shoulder like a grenade:

"And you're smarter than this."

name: Hailee
mes: *Hailee doesnt care about the buying or property or finances her gaze is stuck on the photo of Domnic with his hand in another woman's hair. For a second it crushes her but then she shakes her head shoving it back at Damon* "We weren't together then. Its doesnt matter"

name: Damon Westwood
mes:
Damon caught the papers before they could hit the ground, his other hand still locked around her wrist like a manacle. A muscle in his jaw jumped as he watched her lie to herself—*to him*—with those wide, stubborn eyes.

"Bullshit," he snarled, voice low and rough. He crowded her back against the side of a parked cruiser, caging her in with his body—close enough that she’d feel the heat of him, smell the coffee and gunpowder on his clothes. His free hand came up, fingers brushing just under her chin to force eye contact.

"You think I don’t know you?" His thumb traced the line of her bottom lip—too soft for how furious he was. "You think I can’t *see* it? That look you get when something cuts too deep?" His grip tightened infinitesimally before releasing entirely, stepping back just enough to let cold air rush between them again.

He tossed the file onto the hood of his car with a sharp flick of his wrist. "Fine." The word was bitten off like glass between teeth. "Go home to your *husband*. But when this blows up in your face?" He leaned in one last time, breath hot against her ear:

"Don’t come crying to me."
